text: in this first Berserker Kazan review
we'll take an in-depth look at the first
ever single player arpg set in the
dungeon and fighter universe developed
by neople and published by Nexon and
decide whether this team's first Souls
likee has delivered on the expectations
it generated from its highly praised
demo came out earlier this year in the
first Berserker Kazan you play as Kazan
a warrior of the Pelos Empire Who Rose
through the ranks to become a great
General and alongside his best friend
osma the great Mage they vanquished
Hisar the berserk dragon that threatened
their land and gained their status as
Heroes of the Empire but the emperor
envied their Fame and thus framed the
very people who protected the Empire and
charged them with treason Kazan was then
brutally tortured his tendon severed and
exiled to the snowy mountains of Mount
heimach fate intervenes when an
avalanche disrupts his Transit and in
that moment a being known as the blade
Phantom merges with him in an attempt to
take over his body from here Kazan
manages to form a pact with the blade
Phantom in exchange for helping him with
his mission and the blade Phantom grants
kazon the street R necessary to enact
revenge against those who had wronged
him in return the concept of an inner
demon that we see the protagonist
control is a Trope I've mostly only
encountered in anime and one television
show it really appeals to me since it
allows the opportunity for both
character development and interesting
interactions between the two distinct
personalities sharing one body Kazan and
the blade Phantom execute the dynamic
quite well and their partnership is
engaging because they have such opposing
personalities blade Phantom looks down
on human connection and heroism whereas
Kazan is the very embodiment of those
ideals however in terms of character
growth kazon and blade Phantom don't
change throughout the story and
unfortunately this is the same for many
other characters as well Additionally
the side characters introduced into the
narrative always had one moment of
importance only to be sidelined when
they could have had an interesting
Spotlight given their intriguing Origins
and their skills once you progress
further into the game you experience
many twists and turns some of which
genuinely surprised me and made me feel
sympathetic towards some characters the
story stays engaging throughout all the
way to the climax where Mysteries are
unveiled which is only elevated by
fantastically executed visuals and
gameplay the fact that it's a Revenge
story focused on the climax of The Pelos
Empire is also a nice bonus since Souls
likes generally explore the aftermath of
a great civilization falling so the main
objective of Kazan story is somewhat
different when compared to other Souls
likes one more note on the story I think
is worth mentioning is that the game
adds a full character relationship map
accessible from any blade Nexus this
adds additional info for all the
characters you've met playing their
allegiance and adds info to their
biography as the game goes on which I
found was a nice touch for anyone like
me who wanted a deeper dive into the
characters the setting of the dungeon
and fighter Universe also plays a huge
role in The Narrative and overall
atmosphere of the game consisting of the
existence of Mages powerful dragons
reptilian dragonkin Seno Temple monks
giant Yeti monsters a ruler of the
underworld and much much more the World
building also shaped the world around
Kazan like the dragon can race and their
Newfound grudge against humanity after
the defeat Fe of Hisar which is shown in
the aftermath of Dragon Kin and human
Wars in some missions the Nether world
and its hierarchy is also touched upon
as an important origin story for the
blade Phantom which the game will reveal
in later stages overall the story and
setting of the first Berserker Kazan is
engaging from start to finish with an
interesting story not commonly told in
video game format that feels fresh and
the dungeon and fighter setting executed
in a way that anyone could understand
unfortunately character development is
lacking and some characters I would have
liked to see more of were not expanded
upon beyond their initial moments of
Glory but the setting and the Mysteries
beyond the plot kept me immersed the
whole
way although the first preser Kazan does
offer an immersive Story the game
definitely places much more emphasis on
gameplay streamlining some of the basic
Souls like mechanics to attract a wider
audience while drawing significant
inspiration from several Souls likee
titles especially Nea the strongest
aspect of Kazan is the combat system
which is arguably one of the best we've
seen in the last couple years of gaming
perhaps only rivaled by Stellar blade
to begin let's delve into the game's
core structure and level design it would
not be a stretch to say that the first
Berserker Kazan takes a lot of
inspiration from other titles when it
comes to the fundamental gameplay
structure and level design the main Hub
known as the crevice exists in between
the neor and the Mortal realm serving as
your fast travel point to missions to
travel you interact with a phantom gate
which opens a map to the region along
with Mission details recommended levels
and unlocked Collectibles once you
complete all main missions in the region
you unlock the staircase leading to the
next Phantom Gate in the kevis and you
repeat this Loop for the full game this
Hub structure is very akin to the Nexus
from Demon Souls with its ARG Stones
while the mission selection is straight
out of neo2 which actually Blends
surprisingly well this combination
brings out the best of both games the
demon soul style Hub with the arch
stones that allows you to feel more
connected with the NPCs and offers a
sense of Safe Haven while the neo2 style
maps and missions provide Clarity with
Mission info and segmentation breaking
the game into manageable objectives for
players with limited time however I do
wish the Hub had more hidden elements or
loot as secrets and treasures always
seem to be key elements in the soul
series The crevice ends up feeling quite
lackluster on that front as for the
actual missions in the game and level
design Kazan deceives You by starting
incredibly linear and quite boring but
slowly and gradually eases into more
complex and longer missions with
verticality shortcuts missable content
and even hidden walls and secret
bookshelf doors levels are often heavily
inspired by multiple Souls like titles
such as the burning Villages from Neo
sends Fortress in an Orlando from Dark
Souls or even classic Miyazaki poison
swamps Collectibles are also present
throughout levels with a few breakable
red gems that can be exchanged for
bonuses and later on jarlings who are
showing off their Neo inspiration loud
and proud with zero shame as they
operate much the way Kodama did there
are even Remnant corpses that have
dialogue when you interact with them and
missions always end with a signature
boss and a mission completed so the devs
may just be the biggest Neo fans in the
gaming industry if I were to compare
level designs between this game and
other Souls likes I would say this game
reaches somewhere around a demon souls
level at its peak which is unfortunately
only the final two regions of the game
for a few missions I can confidently say
that it was an experience different from
any other Souls like as for the rest
though it felt like I already knew all
the tricks and traps from other titles
they had been inspired by this doesn't
mean I didn't enjoy them though as they
were still very fun and were executed
nearly flawlessly which is quite
impressive for a company that has never
created an arpg never mind a Soul's
light
overall the game structure is quite
cleverly done and mission level design
starts weak but ends off very strong
perhaps a bit too much inspiration was
taken for the levels but they were still
very enjoyable nonetheless moving on
from the game structure let's finally
talk about what we're all here for the
combat the combat in this game is filled
with tons of fresh ideas that would
belong in a Devil May Cry title instead
sneaking its way into a Souls like game
and the results speak for themselves the
gam playay feels visceral with topnotch
animation sound effects and hit stop
frames that all culminate in excellent
satisfying combat which almost turns the
game into a hack and slash however the
patience required from bosses will
humble you if you treat the game as such
forcing you to get good with parries and
or dodging to truly Master Kazan they
even have special burst counter moves
again straight out of Neo which are also
very satisfying and rewarding Kazan has
found a nice balance between the
patience required from the player and
the aggressive tools given to them so
that fights aren't too fast from players
spamming and not respecting enemies or
or too slow from excessive enemy attacks
that heavily punish you at the core of
customization for the combat is of
course leveling up you acquire another
world Essence called laca from corpses
defeating enemies and bosses that you
can then use to level your stats which
aren't very different from other Souls
likee titles Additionally you heal with
Nether world energy that replenishes at
every checkpoint you activate there are
three different weapon types you can
choose from the game the dual wield
which has short range but Swift and
Nimble attacks the great sword with its
hard-hitting and defensive moves and the
spear with Long Reach and insane
multi-hit combos all of these weapons
have vastly different play styles that
completely change how you play kazon and
almost make it look entirely different
from one weapon to the other at the core
of this system is the skill tree where
there are very distinct skills and
passive bonuses for each weapon and a
common skill tree for Universal skills
and passives the engine of this system
is Spirit a resource you gain by
attacking enemies and perfectly pairing
them which you can use to activate
skills that you've unlocked in the skill
tree skills will either be baked into
your weapon combo or be a separate input
costing Spirit or be part of a weapon
move that also costs spirit it's very
easy to start picking your favorites
based on the feel and Effectiveness by
just trying skills and moves out on
enemies and then changing around skill
points with no additional cost to try
others the only problem I would say with
this skill tree system is that some
skills will be fundamentally stronger
than others such as your charged heavy
attack getting a damage boost or just
getting extra reach and a combo added on
but the game resolves any of these
issues by also incorporating sets and
skills acquired from full set bonuses
from your gear gear in this game
includes your weapon Helm armor gloves
leggings boots ring and necklace the
only difference between the geiger that
you pick up are the set it's related to
and the random attributes it rolls
you'll never find a weapon with higher
attack damage than another assuming that
it drops at the same level in Rarity so
the build customization in this game is
generally from your chosen set and those
random attributes you can mix and match
sets but to acquire skills from the set
you generally need between five to eight
pieces I won't be showing any of those
acquired skills here because a huge part
of the fun is just discovering them
yourself but I will say from personal
experience that they are probably the
flashiest most powerful skills in the
game and I had tons of fun just
discovering the different set skills by
crafting them all you can also equip
Phantoms which gives some passive Buffs
to your character to support your chosen
skills and these can be upgraded with
discoverable items and XP as you
progress the game all in all though
there is honestly not a ton of
customization which results in rather
weak build variety it's very streamlined
to just be attribute bonuses sets
Phantom skills and stats streamlining is
not necessarily a bad thing but to some
extent it does harm replayability and
narrow the scope of possible builds
overall though it's complex enough to
keep you invested in your build every
time you return to the crevice after a
mission the Highlight is the secret
skills you find on sets lastly for
gameplay let's talk about enemy variety
the pool is quite sizable with over 80
different enemies spread across your
playthrough with almost all of them
boasting a unique move move set there's
also an Arachnophobia mode to turn your
spiders into creepy robots if you want
which I found pretty funny there will
sometimes be elite enemies in a mission
featuring a base enemy in frenzy with
extra health and true to form there's
some very annoying enemies that will
grow on you just like our favorite death
basilis from Dark Souls in terms of
bosses the main mission bosses are all
unique and Incredibly welld designed I
spent hours doing no damage runs for
most of them because it's just that fun
for the bonus missions bosses are decent
being creative outakes of the main
bosses and other times just being weaker
copies of it moving on to design the
first bersuka Kazan is Practically
Perfect in terms of optimization with my
game running at a very smooth 90 FPS on
all Max settings at 1440p with an Nvidia
3090 and an AMD risen 9
550x the graphics of the game are decent
but the real star of the show is the art
style with very good looking cell-shaded
characters and a perfect Bleak color
palette to nail the feeling of a gritty
Revenge story heavily emphasizing the
colors of black and red when Interac
with anything related to the ne world or
using skills in combat in terms of audio
the soundtracks are great they aren't on
the level of lives of he or Stellar
blade but they work in making me hyped
up for boss fights or dispirited when
facing tragedy the English voice acting
is Stellar with well-known industry
professionals who you probably know of
making an appearance primarily Anthony
Howell who plays marget and Elden ring
as blade Phantom Ben star who plays
clyve rosfeld in Final Fantasy 16 as
Kazan and Holly Earl as Lilia from
League of Legends playing defa just a
few minor issues are keeping the design
of Kazan from being perfect emphasizing
the red leaves some missions in areas
seem washed out when exploring which
could be a designed Choice since the
story is O Bleak tragedy but is still
somewhat off ping additionally there
were a few minor bugs in my playthrough
and there were a few rare frame drops in
the last couple of missions perhaps from
90 to 50 or 60 or so but it didn't
really Impact gameplay at
all a player completely new to souls
like games may take around 80 hours to
beat the game on the normal difficulty
but the average soulslike player will
likely beat the game in around 40 hours
and collect everything in 20 making the
total 60 hours for a completionist
playthrough the limitations on gameplay
customization do harm that replayability
somewhat but playing with a different
weapon will feel like a completely
different experience there's also a new
game plus with additional items and loot
to find so a second playthrough is
probably a must but a third would be a
stretch when considering A Game's price
point we take into account the amount of
content available the experience impact
and the value of purchasing a game right
away versus waiting for patches or a
sale priced at $59.99 USD on both
console and PC the first Berserker Kazan
is well worth your money for such a high
production value product with some real
passion behind it you can tell these
devs Must Have Spent months analyzing
and picking apart all the different
Souls titles they took inspiration from
and though their first attempt may not
have much unique from these titles it's
a fantastic starting point for their
future
games final thoughts their first preser
gazan has been on my wish list for over
a year now I remember being incredibly
hyped to play The Moment I Saw the cell
shaded soulslike trailer that almost
looked like a berserk game coming to
life so has the game lived up to the
hype in my eyes I would say absolutely
yes the game has everything I expected
and wanted it to have a dramatic and
slightly edgy Revenge story visceral
combat that feels like a fast-paced
expanded version of sakiro and a
fantastic art style with cell shading to
give it that Mana anime aesthetic
despite having interesting characters
who make hardly any appearance than the
lack of character development from Kazan
and blade Phantom I still found myself
enjoying the story for its plot-driven
narrative serving as an incentive enough
to keep pushing forward through all the
tough obstacles you faed in the game the
excellent Technical and visual aspects
carry the main story with fantastic Boss
Designs and effects that make climactic
moments feel exceptionally dramatic
these bosses are also the most fun
content the game has to offer which was
the main thing I was looking for in
Kazan it's just a shame that
customization and thus replayability are
slightly lacking since I always found
myself craving to spend more time in the
crevice tinkering with my build but I'm
sure this could be expanded upon in
future titles or maybe even a DLC the
big budget from the dungeon and fighter
series really shows in this title and
it's an extremely solid game for $59.99
easily making it my second favorite game
this year so far just behind monster on
of Wilds I highly recommend you grab
this day one if you're a fan of titles
such as Ziro Devil May Cry 5 or
Neon w
[Music]
[Music]
